newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo stocks seen climbing after Wall St surge.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo stocks seen climbing after Wall St surge.

text.p: Tokyo stocks are likely to climb on Monday, helped by a surge in Wall Street stocks on Friday. But the stronger yen against the dollar is expected to keep investors from aggressively buying export-oriented shares, limiting the upside of the key market index, brokers said.
On Friday, the 225-share Nikkei average finished at 20,485.75, down 2.40 points or 0.01 percent. Its June futures added 30 to end at 20,500.
"The Nikkei average is likely to reach at least 20,600 today," said Yasuo Ueki, general manager of the equities operations group at Nikko Securities Co Ltd.
"A rise in U.S. stocks will stimulate buying in Tokyo, but the higher yen could partly offset any buying," said a broker at a medium-sized Japanese securities house.
On Friday, the Dow industrials leapt 130.49 points to end at a record high of 7,435.78, after a monthly employment report reinforced investors' positive outlook on the U.S. economy.
The dollar traded at 113.80/90 yen in early Asia trade on Monday, against 115.70/80 yen in late Friday trade in Tokyo.
Nikko's Ueki said investors would be interested in domestic economy-oriented sectors, such as raw materials, semiconductors, retail and real estate.
